message.content:
a fisherman caught 30 fish in 5 days, so he catches an average of 30 / 5 = <<30/5=6>>6 fish per day.

If he takes a break after every two days of fishing, then within one cycle consisting of four days (two working , two resting), he would catch a total of

2 * 6 = <<2*6=12>>12 fish

In order to catch at least 60 fish, we can do the following calculations:

1. Find how many cycles are necessary:
60 ÷ 12 ≈ <<60/12=5>>5
We find that it's not enough for him to complete just four cycles because with them he would be able to catch only: 

4 (cycles) × 12fish = <<4*12=48>>48fish – which is less than what we need.

Therefore our answer here is five cycles;

2. Find out how many days those five cycles will take :
Each cycle has four days;
Thus:

Number_of_days_for_fishing_catch_ Fish ≥ Number_of_cycles×(days_in_each_cycle)≥  
Days≥_Length_of_interval−1 ;
The length of interval L=fish_rate *(the number_of_days_on +the_number _of_days_off). So in our case :

Days≥60-1+ [(5 )(complete_duration_period)];

However for convenience ,we may notice that; since within each full_complete week duration period consists exactly 
a_frame_time =(4×)(number_working_shift)=[(number_day/week)-((active_working/saturday)][experimental_direction_set]
#=3minute_greeting
